author: jaspa.codes
content: Hey all, I was looking at EIP-1559 yesterday and was trying to understand incentives for miners and users. Am I right in understanding that the reason miners don't simply fill every block to maximise tips is because the tip may be lower than the expected loss from processing an additional transaction? Which means tips above a certain level are always included and those below won't be? Also presumably this price in gwei can be fairly closely calculated.

author: sky.cactus
content: Filling a block will increase the base fee (which miners don't get) for the *next* block.  Also, you have to pay the base fee (which is burned, so this is a real cost) to fill the block with transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: As far as what the gas premium miners will require, it is based on increased uncle risk as you implied.  Estimates floating around are between 1 nanoeth and 5 nanoeth depending on an individual block's value (which can vary based on fees collected for that block).

author: jaspa.codes
content: Right but that cost is not paid by the miners. You're saying if the price increases there will be less than 50% of the block worth of transactions willing to pay, losing out on business?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes.

author: sky.cactus
content: The system is designed so the price will increase until blocks are only half full.

author: sky.cactus
content: Basically, the fee increases until demand for blockspace drops sufficiently.

author: jaspa.codes
content: Right, but surely there's a minimum, which is a point where they'd mine empty blocks instead. And just above that is where most users should sit the majority of the time. It'll only go way up in times of sudden increases.

author: sky.cactus
content: A minimum what?

author: sky.cactus
content: Premium?

author: sky.cactus
content: Or base fee?

author: jaspa.codes
content: Yeah, gas price

author: jaspa.codes
content: Minimum miner tip

author: sky.cactus
content: There is no gas price anymore.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: There is the premium (sometimes incorrectly called "tip"), and there is the base fee.

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners will individually configure a minimum gas premium that they are willing to accept.  We expect this to be between 1 nanoeth/gas and 5 nanoeth/gas if miners are rational and our math and estimates are correct.

author: sky.cactus
content: Any transactions below a miners minimum configured premium will simply not be included in any blocks that miner produces.

author: jaspa.codes
content: Right, I understand, what I'm saying is, it feels like when basefee prices are fairly stable, most people only have an incentive to set a premium which is only high enough that it offsets the time to process the extra transaction (assuming everyone is setting a minimal premium).

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, this is exactly correct and expected behavior.

author: jaspa.codes
content: Ok cool ðŸ™‚

author: jaspa.codes
content: Thanks!

author: sky.cactus
content: Well, offsets uncle risk + epsilon.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content: The miners won't include something with a 0 EV.  ðŸ˜‰

author: sky.cactus
content: But +epsilon EV they will if rational.

author: jaspa.codes
content: Another question - am I right in assuming miners expected returns overall will drop with EIP-1559 and hence there will be an expected drop in difficulty after the implementation? If so are there any estimates on what the change will be like?

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes to the first, assuming all else is equal.

author: sky.cactus
content: Whether there is a comensurate drop in difficulty depends on whether miners are currently barely profitable or not.

author: sky.cactus
content: If they have some breathing room (which is likely I think) they won't shutdown.

author: jaspa.codes
content: Right, that all makes sense.
